day 20 spotify improving station what it is

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

Day 20: Spotify Improving Station

What it is: When listening to Spotify’s radio, the thumbs up icon tells you that it’s improving the station before adding it to a playlist for you.

Why it’s good: First, the pause is brilliant. I’m sure Spotify doesn’t need any processing time to pick the next song, but this brief pause makes me feel like they’re actually doing something important. The reason that it works to make me wait for a second is that it’s unlikely at this point that I would want to do something else, so the action doesn’t block me.

The part that elevates this to an amazing design is automatically adding it to a playlist. Liking a song to improve a station is a concept that I’m used to because of Pandora. Adding it to a list where I can find it later (and play it by itself) is a direct sell of Spotify’s added value - You can listen to it on the radio, but you can also listen to it by itself. Even though it’s subtle, this interface piece underscores that value proposition.

day 19 google now gas stations what it is when

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

Day 19: Google Now Gas Stations

What it is: When travelling home from Philadelphia this past weekend, I brought up Google Now. It showed me a list of gas stations off of my route, and the amount of time the detour would take.

Why it’s good: It’s been fascinating to watch Google make changes to Now as it’s evolved as a product. When Now first started, it only had the ability to tell you things that were near to you. Useful, sure, but not so much when you’re speeding down an interstate.

This use case is an exact compliment to my needs, it was exactly what my wife and I needed as we travelled down the interstate. The biggest challenge is I don’t know how to make it appear, but Google guessed correctly and made it surface at the right time.

Now I just need it to do the same thing Coffee shops

day 18 starbucks case tumbler what it is

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

Day 18: Starbucks Case + Tumbler

What it is: Starbucks recently released a line of tumblers in which you can customize the case. The labels on these use alternating color and blind deboss to indicate they are parts of a set.

Why it’s good: It’s hard to indicate to users when they need to pay attention. In software, we have a lot of ways to handle this by locking down the system until certain requirements have been fulfilled. We don’t always have that option though.

This little set is more subtle than slapping big numbers on the tumbler and case, but it provides the same effect. The blind deboss is different, it catches attention enough that you realize that there’s another level of information. Put next to eachother, the relationship is clear instantly.

day 17 500px terms privacy what it is 500px

100daysofgoodux100DaysProject

Day 17: 500px Terms & Privacy

What it is: 500px is a photo sharing and discovery site. Their terms and conditions are a 2 column page, the left column is all the legal-ese required to run a large site, and they then explain it on the right.

Why it’s good: EULA’s and legal text in general are terrible experiences. If each interpersonal relationship began with a 10 minute recitation of what you were agreeing to by entering into this relationship, being a hermit would be much more socially acceptable.

Some products decide to address this by shaming the user into reading the EULA that they’ve agreed to sight unseen. While it makes a product developer feel better, it doesn’t really encourage anyone to enter the situation with more knowledge. 500px takes a different route, it gets that you want to understand what you’re agreeing to, and then gives you the ability to bridge that gap.

The brilliant part of this design is in the juxtaposition. Instead of just writing a long document and then a simplified version, laying it side by side makes me feel as a user that this is an accurate translation. The large copy and short sentences make it easy to scan and understand. It gives me a quicker way to get the same information, which is brilliant.

day 16 bellroy product line note this is based

100daysofgoodux100DaysProject

Day 16: Bellroy Product Line

Note: This is based on an earlier version of the Bellroy website which you can see at archive.org

What is is: Bellroy is a steadily growing line of “every day carry” items. They began with wallets, which is still the majority of their product line. When they just sold wallets, they arranged their products on a continuum of features, going from “Slimmest” to “Most features.”

Why it’s good: Product lines can be difficult to explain well to an end user. How do you go about showing the difference between the products and helping the user identify the right solution for their needs?

I’ve come back to this particular idea so many times because of how breathtakingly clear it was to me when I was purchasing a wallet from this company. I instantly knew what tradeoffs I was making, and felt like I had a good sense of accomodating my needs. The categorization above the wallets functioned as a breakpoint, helping me determine where exactly my needs lay.

The secondary effect was helping me “fuzzy find” what I wanted. While I wasn’t sure exactly which wallet was right for me, having them displayed in a range like this helped me determine what I didn’t need right off the bat. I spent very little time looking above the “Hide and Seek” or below the “Slim Sleeve” because the range defined where my dividing line was for features that I wanted or needed.

While I was sad to see them iterate away from it, it’s great to see that they didn’t let a great idea hinder the growth of their product line. Clinging to this narrative wouldn’t have made sense when they added phone cases or a more rugged line (The features are different, not just more)
